entry.para: • Inform the patient about the nature and purpose of the assessment process and allow them to ask questions
• Use validated, standardized assessment tools such as semi-structured or structured interviews
• Follow-up on a positive bipolar disorder results from a screening measure with a more thorough assessment interview
• Incorporate feedback from additional sources such as the patient’s family or other providers when available
• Screen for comorbid disorders, such as anxiety and substance use disorders
• Conduct a thorough safety assessment to assess for suicidality and risk of harm to others
• Screen for hypomania and mania among individuals presenting with depressive symptoms, even if they don’t initially mention any periods of elevated mood
• Consider the patient’s social and cultural background as it may relate to the manifestation of their symptoms and the ways they describe their illness
• Administer an assessment measure that you have not been properly trained in
• Obtain information from additional sources without verifying whether you need the patient’s informed consent
• Rely exclusively on screening measures to make diagnostic decisions
• Provide a diagnosis of depression without confirming that the patient has no history of manic or hypomanic symptoms
• Assume that a patient has not experienced hypomania or mania just because they do not describe their symptoms as being problematic
• Over-pathologize behaviors and beliefs that may be normative within a patient’s culture, or mischaracterize symptoms based on cultural differences in the manifestation of psychopathology
